The District owns miscellaneous property that has been replaced with new (See attached Surplus Forms, 15 pages).  The property has been determined to be in such poor condition that it is unusable. District staff estimates the resale value to be less than $100.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous surplus property that has been determined to be of no further use to the District (see attached Surplus Disposal Forms, 7 pages). The estimated aggregate market value of the surplus property is less than $5,000.00. 
	 
California Education Code 81452 provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), of if the property is of sufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, then it may be sold or disposed by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
    Purchasing Services will call for competitive bids on the Public Surplus website and sell the items to the highest responsive bidders. If the property does not sell, then it will be disposed in accordance with Education Code 81452. Any proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the surplus property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to sell or dispose of the items in accordance with Education Code 81452.

 The District has 10 pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 12 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As noted in the December 10, 2012, Board Agenda item titled “Update on Proposition 30, Education Protection Account," the language in Proposition 30 requires that all California community college districts have sole authority to determine how the moneys received from the Education Protection Account are spent in the school or schools within its jurisdiction, provided:
The appropriate governing board or body shall make these spending determinations in open session of a public meeting of the governing board or body and shall not use any of the funds from the Education Protection Account for salaries or benefits of administrators or any other administrative costs
Shall annually publish on its Internet Website an accounting of how much money was received from the Education Protection Account and how that money was spent
Shall, in addition to all other requirements of law, ascertain and verify through the annual independent audit whether the funds provided from the Education Protection Account have been properly disbursed and expended as required by this section.
On April 03, 2013, the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office issued an Accounting Advisory (attached) to assist districts with compliance for the language in Proposition 30, as noted above.
	 
This Board action contains the recommended spending plan for the District’s Proposition 30 allocation for the 2012-13 fiscal year per the proposition’s guidelines and the Accounting Advisory (see attached report).
	 
The current estimate from the state chancellor’s office for funds that the District will receive from the Educational Protection Act (EPA) is $23,570,265. It is relevant to note that this is not new, additional funding to the District. The $23 million is a re-designation of what the District would have received in general state apportionment and prevented the district from experiencing approximately $7 million more in cuts to our overall funding. The District will apply these re-designated funds as needed to the instructional and student support categories included in the spending plan until the amount received from the EPA is reached. No funds will be applied to administrator’s salaries or benefits, or any other administrative costs. The District will post on its website an accounting of what the final 2012-13 allocation of EPA funds was to the District and how it was expended. This will not take place until late September after the financial books for 2012-13 have been closed. Additionally the expenditure of the funds will be included in the CCFS-311 report to the state chancellor’s office and the annual financial audit will include verification that the funds were used as required by Proposition 30.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy x6201
Additional contact names:
Joni Hayes Lamprey x6261
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approve the 2012-13 Spending Plan for the Proposition 30, Educational Protection Account

items.item_text_raw: 10. 2012-13 Spending Plan for the Proposition 30, Educational Protection Account

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
On April 21, 2010, the District entered into a three-year Application Subscription Program Agreement with TouchNet Information Systems, Inc. (TouchNet) to provide an on-line student credit card payment authorization plan; this plan allows our students to pay their tuition and fees on-line through an easy-to-use payment gateway service. This service authenticates the student’s credit card payment with his/her banking institution and records the payment transactions; the transaction history reconciles with the Banner student accounts on a daily basis.  The current annual cost is $21,840.50.  The District successfully processed approximately $48.6 million dollars of student tuition and fees, per year, through the current payment gateway service.
	 
Request to add the additional student installment plan and electronic checking service components:
Based on the request from both colleges to help meet the registration payment needs of the students, the District’s ETS staff requests to add two additional service components to the current credit card payment gateway service from TouchNet.  The First Addendum to the Application Subscription Program Agreement would extend the original services for an additional five years and include the additional service components.
        1. The installment plan will provide service to the students who cannot pay tuition and fees all at once, at the time of registration; students can elect to enroll in a self-service payment plan by this service, they will have the opportunity to divide their payments into pre-defined schedules and pay off the balance gradually.
        2. The additional electronic checking component will provide service to students and parents, who do not have a credit card; an alternative way to pay tuition and fees directly from their checking accounts (ACH transctions).
The total annual cost for the added components plus the original payment gateway will be $73,825 (subject to an annual escalation not to exceed 5%), and is prorated for May and June 2013 at a cost of $3,822.  A one-time implementation and set-up cost for the additional components will be $31,575.  Total cost for implementation and license fee through June 30, 2014 will be $109,222.
	 
Analysis:
TouchNet has provided electronic payment services to the District for many years. They process all of our credit card payments from students over the web.   Over those years TouchNet has become deeply embedded in the District’s information systems, particularly since we have implemented the Banner Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system.  In addition, ETS staff has spent considerable time and effort making sure that all our ecommerce transactions through TouchNet are fully compliant with PCI-DSS (credit card security) standards.  
	 
ETS now wish to add additional e-commerce options for students – a self-service payment plan administration and ACH transaction (electronic checks) processing. These services are available from TouchNet. Payment processing systems are available from other vendors; however, they are not compatible with the currently installed payment-processing infrastructure we operate. If the District were to prepare a bid specification for the two additional service components, only TouchNet would be a responsive bidder.  This is because:
In order to provide consistent service to students and manageable functionality for support staff, all ecommerce payment functions need to be provided through a single user interface.  Essentially, all services must come from the same vendor. 
Due to significant technical and funding constraints we really cannot consider removing existing TouchNet services to migrate to another vendor.   
Additionally, Ellucian (maker of the Banner system) has recently announced that TouchNet is their primary partner for electronic payment processing services.  Subsequently, the District will receive the highest level of support for payment processing integration by staying with TouchNet.
	 
There are also a couple of other features that are unique to the services provided by TouchNet that other vendors do not have:  
1.)  TouchNet does not charge students a fee for payment plan processing, whereas other vendors do not provide this option, and 
2.)  All of TouchNet’s transaction processing is done in real time which makes it easier for technical and functional staff to reconcile student payments.  Other vendors only offer nightly batch processing.
	 
In view of the complexity and impacts it may cause to replace the current exiting contract for the payment gateway service, and to add associated components by another vendor, ETS requests the board’s approval to enter a sole source contract to include the additional installment plan and electronic checking services to our existing agreement, and extend the TouchNet contract for another five (5) years.
The First Addendum to the Application Subscription Program agreement and the request to enter into a contract without conducting a competitive bid process was reviewed by District legal counsel, Mr. John Shupe of Lynch and Shupe, LLP.  Mr. Shupe supports the approval of this board action item based upon the facts and information provided by the Educational Technology Services department.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih, Director of Information Systems & Operations, x 6139
Is backup provided?
Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College seeks board approval for application to the State Chancellor's Office for the certificate of achievement.  This certificate meets the requirements established by the State Chancellor’s Office.
	 
The Associate in Arts Degree in Music History/Literature is a comprehensive course of study preparing the student to transfer to a four-year institution in music or a music related field. Through the study of Music History/Literature, students examine music masterpieces from multiple eras and cultures, synthesizing information and making judgments as they evaluate how music reflects individual composers’ lives as well as the contemporary social/historical context in which the compositions were created and performed.
	 
The new certificate has been approved by Foothill's curriculum committee.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On March 21, 2013, the Associated Students of Foothill College Campus Council approved the budget for the fiscal year 2013-2014. 
	 
Statewide budget cuts continue to affect campus services and programs at Foothill College in the upcoming year.  With that being said, we were mindful about how ASFC could best support these services and programs that help students succeed. Additionally, we were able to access and spend down a portion of our Fund Balance. 
	 
The manner in which ASFC provides funding to the campus community is based on our mission-based vision & goals, which are approved and adopted by members of ASFC every year. Our deliberation process began much earlier than previous years. We wanted to ensure that every decision we made was in accordance with our mission-based vision and goals, so we began our process in early fall. This year, the budget development process went smoothly thanks to the collaborative work done by the budget team.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
    The De Anza College Child Development Center (CDC) requires a contractor who can provide and deliver meals and snacks for the children who are enrolled in the CDC program.  The meals to be served under this contract must meet the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)-Title 7: Agriculture, Part 226, Child and Adult Food Program requirements and the State of California, Department of Education requirements. 
 
The bid specification requires that vendors provide pricing for breakfast, lunch, snacks, and milk for 233 days per fiscal year to feed approximately 138 children between the ages of 18 months and 6 years old.  The meals are to be delivered daily Monday through Friday and must be ready to serve, family style. The meals are based on an 11-day menu cycle required by the State of California.  The CDC serves a culturally diverse population, and menus that reflect the range of cultures are preferred.  Fresh foods are emphasized.  Dietary restrictions due to allergy, disability, or religion are accommodated.  
 
The Invitation to Bid 1626 was advertised on February 4, 2013 and February 11, 2013.  The bid was sent to six (6) vendors and it was also posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com. Bids were due on March 11, 2013.  Only one bid was received. The current contractor, Bigbreak LLC, dba Chefables, submitted the bid.  Chefables has been providing meals for the CDC since August 1, 2012.  The CDC has been happy with Chefables performance and the quality of the meals that are being served to the children.  Both the CDC and Chefables have been working towards a common goal of having high quality and nutritious food being served.  Chefables also provides food delivery services to other public agencies in the Bay Area including College of San Mateo and San Francisco State Head Start.
 
The total annual FY 13-14 expenditure for breakfasts, lunches, and snacks will be $115,500 based upon the bid price submitted from Chefables.  The flat fee prices are firm during the first year and any price adjustment after the first year (if the contract is renewed) shall be negotiated. Compared to the prices currently being paid, this bid results in over an 11% reduction in the prices of meals and snacks.  The State of California provides approximately $30,000 in reimbursement funds annually for this program.  The balance of the funding comes from private-fee based tuitions, as well as State of California child development subsidies.
	 
	 
Submitted by:
  Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Dawn Allshouse, Senior Buyer and Naoko Harada, Director Childcare Center
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to award a one-year agreement in the amount of $115,500 renewable for up to four additional years to Bigbreak, LLC doing business as Chefables pursuant to Bid 1626.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 18, 2012, the Board of Trustees rejected all bids for Bid 1348-420 District Office Building Renovation.  That project consisted of three primary scopes of work; (1) renovation of the District Office Building, (2) renovation of existing modular trailers to house District staff during the renovation period, and (3) site work for additional modular trailers. Only two bids were received and the lowest responsive bid price received was 14.8% over the construction budget.  The board was advised that District staff would revise the scopes of work and rebid the work in the future. The site work for the modular trailers was completed in Project #105 and the District Office Building Renovation project will bid in early summer.  Construction is expected to start in early fall.
	 
This project, the District Office Building (DOB) Swing Space, consists of an interior renovation of existing modular buildings including demolition; framing; drywall; flooring, finishes; mechanical, electrical, plumbing infrastructure; bathroom; fire alarm; and telecommunications. The project will also include some site work in the adjacent areas.
	 
Cody Anderson Wasney Architects prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1348-420A was legally advertised on February 19 and February 26, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on April 2, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTOR
BASE BID AMOUNT
Calstate Construction, Inc.
$515,000
RC Benson & Sons, Inc.
$541,284
Hallmark Construction
$557,700
Beals Martin and Associates, Inc.
$564,687
B Bros Construction, Inc.
$583,660
Hoi’s Construction Inc.
$616,000
Romkon, Inc.
$695,000
Rodan Builders Inc.
$708,000
	 
The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Calstate Construction, Inc. Calstate Construction, Inc. successfully completed Project #109 – PE Lab Space Remodel at Foothill College, Project #247 – G Building at De Anza College, and also Project #252/100F – Elevator Repairs for both Foothill and De Anza colleges.
	 
The bid price of $515,000 as submitted by Calstate Construction, Inc. is well within the architect’s construction estimate of $791,805 and the construction budget of $792,000. In addition, an addendum that simplified the electrical specification reduced the cost of that portion of the work by $40-50,000. As anticipated, bidding the DOB Swing Space separately from the District Office Renovation resulted in lower bids for the swing space renovation than those received when the two were bid together.  The project will be constructed with Measure E funds.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1348-420A, in the amount of $515,000 to Calstate Construction, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In the process of subdividing the lands of the Onizuka Air Force Station for the closure and reuse of that base, the Air Force drew parcel boundary lines such that some existing buildings lie on more than one parcel. Buildings 1004, 1005 and 1042 will be owned jointly by the District and the City of Sunnyvale (City).  Similar building conditions exist at the property line shared with the Veterans Administration (VA), and an agreement similar to the attached has already been negotiated with the VA.  
                
Both the District and the City desire to demolish the jointly-owned buildings.  The District expects to begin demolition work on the site before the City, so this Memorandum of Agreement provides for complete removal of the jointly-owned buildings by the District’s contractors.  In addition, and in order to take advantage of the cost effectiveness of using a fully mobilized demolition contractor, the District’s contractor will remove four small buildings and minor site improvements located wholly on the City’s site. The satellite dish and its associated buildings (1020, 1021, 1022) in the southwest corner of the site at the intersection of Innovation Way and W. Moffett Park Drive will not be demolished.  
	 
The proportionate costs of demolition design, project management, demolition, related consultants, and Measure C overhead will be reimbursed to the District by the City, at a cost not to exceed $400,000.  The District’s estimated cost for the work is $290,000.  However, the District agrees to defer the City’s payment of its Proportionate Share until three (3) years after the date of this Agreement or upon the sale of Parcel D by the City to a third party, whichever event occurs earlier.  This agreement does not include any interest payments on the loan in recognition of the mutual benefit of prompt development of site to both the District and the City, in recognition of the multiple upcoming coordination and cooperation opportunities that will be required between the District and the City as the site is developed to its full potential, and in recognition of the very low interest rates that would be applicable to such a loan.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management,  extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Kevin McElroy x 6201, Art Heinrich x 6295
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Prime Contract Change Order #2
Vendor:  Sundt Construction
Agreement Date:  November 5, 2012
Campus: De Anza College
Project Number: 245
Project Name:  ATC
Amount: $186,424
For:
	 
Prime Contract Change Order #001, PCO#003, was previously approved to make revisions to the number and location of floor boxes for electrical and data on the 2nd and 3rd floors due to program changes.  PCO#004 & PCO#005 are additional changes that are dictated by the program changes as follows:
	 
1)   Consolidation of Creative Arts on the 1st floor 
2)   Consolidation of Language Arts on the 3rd floor
3)   Reconfiguration of Business / Computer Systems on the 2nd floor to accommodate revised / 
      improved instructional spaces including;
Reconfiguration of spaces to provide an improved combination of collaborative, conference, and class room spaces
Reconfiguration of layouts with lighter, more flexible furnishings
Additional of power/data “drops” to add capacity and flexibility
Addition of “instructional spaces” including large LCD monitors within conference and open collaborative spaces.
Please see the attached table of program revisions and the associated building design/construction changes. Also attached is a series of floor plans that show the program changes by floor.
	 
The changes for the program moves were developed in a coordinated effort led by the De Anza College VP for Instruction who directed the various moves based on the phase out of Business / Computer Systems (Digital Imaging) due to budget cuts.  Once the moves were confirmed, a series of meetings with the Deans and program staff were held to determine student load, functionality, furniture, and equipment layout (computer and electric) needs. Floor plans were developed by College staff based on this information and reviewed and confirmed with Deans.  A few additional changes were identified when program staff realized that they were going to have to function differently because of the loss of specific staff.  Also, included with the above are the desires of the new Dean of Business - Business / Computer System’s to have the computer lab space on the 2nd floor function differently than previously envisioned.  These changes included floor plan changes with some spaces re-purposed for different functions and the inclusion of multiple large LCD monitors.
	 
On the 3rd floor, Student Success (a unit under Learning Resources) took over space previously occupied by Business / Computer Systems  (Digital Imaging).  With the exception of the Math, Science, Technology Resource Center in S-4, all of Student Success will now be consolidated on the 3rd floor of the ATC.  
	 
PCO#004 – In response to CCD#11, contractor was issued CCD#004 to proceed with ordering electrical and data materials, to begin installation of any required backing, and to modify electrical and data installations in order to help minimize potential schedule impacts.  Total costs not-to-exceed $50,000 - OD
	 
PCO#005 – Revisions required to accommodate all of the program changes in the building that were identified after initial contract award.   The total cost of this change is $129,626 which includes an allowance in the amount of $38,000 for unidentified work that may be directed by Architect and a twenty-three (23) calendar day non-compensable schedule extension - OD 
	 
PCO#006 – Wall Covering Stair#1                $6,798 - OD
	 
The total Change Orders to date represent 3.97% against the original contract amount.  Funding is included in the current budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management,  extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College

Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The scope of work will include removing and cleaning the roof tiles at Buildings L2, L3, & L6 at De Anza College and removing and replacing the waterproofing layer of the tile roofs.  It will also include removing and replacing any damaged wood substrate, replacing the cement plaster at the parapets, and installing new weatherproof coatings on the exterior surfaces.  The parapet caps and flashing will be replaced and repairs will be made to the flat roofs as necessary.  
	 
Allana Buick & Bers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1637-236E was legally advertised on March 14, 2013 and March 21, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on April 18, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
Best Contracting Services, Inc.
$339,565
Stronger Building Services
$398,000
Andy’s Roofing Company, Inc.
$522,400
Alcal Specialty Contracting Inc.
$579,870
Swenson & Associates
$888,000
 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Best Contracting Services, Inc. (Best Contracting). Furthermore, Best Contracting and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
Purchasing Services has confirmed that Best Contracting has successfully completed projects for other public entities such as Acalanes Union High School District and the San Francisco Unified School District.  Best Contracting successfully completed Bid #1120, Building 5100 Roof Replacement at Foothill College in 2008.  
	 
The bid price of $339,565 submitted by Best Contracting is within the construction estimate of $381,400 and it is within the overall Project #236E budget of $901,674.  This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Roseanne Sciacchitano, Tom Armstrong; Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Art Room Lighting and Multimedia Upgrade project is part of Measure C Project #175, Repairs and Upgrades Miscellaneous Projects.  This scope of work will require the contractor to replace existing lighting in rooms 1601 and 1602 with new wall lighting, track lighting, and general surface-wrapped lighting.   The contractor will also install projector mounts and electrical preparation for new multimedia equipment to be installed by ETS.  A lead-containing tackable wallboard will be removed and the interior finishes will be patched and painted.
	 
American Consulting Engineers Electrical Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1629-175 was legally advertised on March 26, 2013 and April 2, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on April 19, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
ER Brothers Company, Inc. 
$106,420.00
Integra Construction Services, Inc. 
$119,000.00
Cupertino Electric, Inc. 
$127,376.00
Rodan Builders, Inc. 
$162,000.00
Omni Construction Services, Inc. 
$168,000.00
	 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder ER Brothers Company, Inc. (ER Brothers).  Purchasing staff has confirmed that ER Brothers have successfully completed projects for other public entities such as City of San Mateo and City of Menlo Park. 
	 
On April 26, 2013 the District received a bid protest letter from Integra Construction Services, Inc. (Integra).  The letter alleges that ER Brothers Company Inc. does not meet the criteria of a responsible bidder.  ER Brothers Company Inc. has responded to each of the six (6) issues or points of concern raised by Integra.  See all attached correspondence letters.  
	 
District Purchasing Staff reviewed the correspondences with the Foothill College Bond Director, Mr. Art Heinrich.  It is his recommendation to proceed with the award to ER Brothers and deny the bid protest from Integra.  District staff also reviewed ER Brothers’ responses with its legal counsel Mr. Phillip Jaret, and he found ER Brothers bid to be legally compliant.  Furthermore, it is the opinion of Mr. Jaret that the award to ER Brothers can go forward but that the work in progress must be carefully monitored. 
	 
The bid price of $106,420 submitted by ER Brothers is within the construction estimate of $115,000 and within the overall Project #175 budget of $500,000.  This project is funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Deny the bid protest submitted by Integra Construction Services, Inc. and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1629-175, Art Room Lighting & Multimedia Upgrade at Foothill College in the amount of $106,420.00 to ER Brothers Company, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 4, 2012 the Board of Trustees authorized a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1422-162 Parking & Circulation – Phase 1 at Foothill College.  This second phase of the Parking and Circulation project includes reconfiguring and resurfacing the District Access Road (between Loop Road and Lot 1H); vehicular and pedestrian circulation improvements to Lot 1; and complete reconstruction of Lot 6.  In addition, four Bid Alternates were included in the bid proposal.  Alternate #1 adds a vehicular and pedestrian bridge over Adobe Creek connecting Lot 1 and the District Road, modifications to Lot 1 entrance, and a traffic signal on Loop Road at the pedestrian crossing from Lot 1. Alternate #2 adds improvements to the multi-use path along Loop Road in front of the District Office.  Alternate #3 adds new lighting for the Loop Road along Lots 5 & 6 and Alternate #4 changes the sidewalk at Lot 6 from concrete to decomposed granite.  The bid document provides that the lowest bid will be the lowest total of the bid prices for the Base Bid Proposal Amount without consideration of the Alternates. 
	 
WRNS Studio prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1640-162 was legally advertised on March 20, 2013 and March 27, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on April 26, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:

The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is OC Jones & Sons, Inc. (OC Jones). Furthermore, OC Jones and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council. OC Jones is currently completing the De Anza College Stadium & Track project.
	 
The plans and specifications for Alternate #1 – Lot 1 bridge, entrance, and traffic signal are not fully approved by the Division of State Architect (DSA).  However, DSA approval is anticipated soon as its review is near completion.  If the scope of work for Alternate #1 does not get approved by May 22, 2013 then that particular scope of work must be placed on hold until next summer.  The Measure C bond team recommends award a contract for the Base Bid Proposal Amount plus Alternate #1 (contingent upon DSA approval, but only if DSA approval is achieved by May 22, 2013), Alternate #2 and Alternate #3. Alternate #4 should not be accepted because a concrete sidewalk is preferable to the decomposed granite sidewalk and it has a longer lifespan.  Upon receipt of a Notice of Award on May 14, 2013, the awarding bidder will be instructed to obtain insurances and bonds in the aggregate amount of the Base Bid Proposal Amount plus Alternate #1, Alternate #2, and Alternate #3.  If DSA approval for Alternate #1 is not obtained by May 22, 2013, the District shall credit back the difference in insurance and bond premium costs for Alternate #1 as a deductive change order.
	 
District Purchasing Staff reviewed the award procedure for Alternate #1 with the Foothill College Bond Director, Mr. Art Heinrich and District’s legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret.  Mr. Jaret supports the decision of the District staff to proceed with the recommendation for the Board of Trustees to award Alternate #1, but only contingent upon DSA approval by May 22,2013. The Notice to Proceed will only include the work for Alternate #1 if DSA approval is received by that date.
	 
The bid price of $4,062,000 for the Base Bid plus Alternates #1 - #3 submitted by OC Jones is slightly over the aggregate construction estimate of $4,000,000 for the work is and it is within the overall Project #162 budget for all phases of work. 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On June 20, 2011 the Board of Trustees authorized a contract for Combined Site Improvements Phase 1.  The second phase of the Combined Site Improvement project includes exterior hardscape, ADA pathway upgrades, landscape irrigation and planting, exterior lighting, and civil work at the Mary Avenue entrance and around the Administration Building.  It also includes an ADA ramp and walkway near the PE buildings.  Alternate #1 is for landscape planting at the Administration Building, including installation labor and any required materials.  Alternate #2 is for the materials and labor to install an ADA ramp, stairs, railings and hardscape at the Northwest side of Building PE 4. The bid document provides that the lowest bid will be the lowest total of the bid prices for the Base Bid Proposal Amount without consideration of the Alternates.
	 
Sandis prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid Document #1471A-274 was legally advertised on March 22, 2013 and March 29, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com. Bids were publicly opened and read on April 17, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:

Furthermore, Guerra and its listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement to be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
Purchasing Services has confirmed that Guerra has successfully completed projects for other public entities such as Sunnyvale School District and St. Helena Unified School District.  Guerra also successfully completed Project #228, CDC Playground Maintenance and Upgrade at De Anza College in 2010.
	 
The bid price of $1,489,700 for the Base Bid plus Alternate #2 submitted by Guerra is over the construction base bid estimate of $1,332,753, however, it is within the overall Project #274A budget of $2,039,558.  Therefore, the Measure C bond team recommends award a contract for the Base Bid Proposal amount plus Alternate #2.  This project is funded by Measure C.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
	On February 27, 2008, the board approved two five-year contracts with SunGard Higher Education (SunGardHE), a Software License & Services Agreement and a Start-up Support / Maintenance Services Agreement, both associated with the procurement of the Banner administrative information system.
	 
	The initial service agreement for the deployment of the Banner system was estimated at $3.6 million dollars. This budget was part of the overall 11.8 million dollar Banner project briefed to the board on February 4, 2008.
	 
	Out of the original 3.6 million dollar implementation budget, 2.1 million dollars was set aside as the initial deployment cost for the Banner system.  These initial costs covered the necessary activities for both our internal staff and outside consultants to deploy the Banner system within the first three years. The remaining 1.6 million dollars was budgeted to extend the functionality to other FHDA departments after the initial system implementation is over.
	 
	We have now reached the five years mark of the original contract. From the original three year deployment process, we amended the purchase order 1 time, for a total amount of $1M, to cover the remaining two years of the initial five years Banner consulting and training needs:
	 
					 
					Original budget

					1st amendment

There is a total remaining balance of $500,000 out of the original board approved implementation budget of 3.6 million dollars. The fund is part of the Measure C funding allocated to the EIS project (Project fund code #350).
	 
Submitted by:
Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih, Director of Information Systems & Operations, x 6139
